Tasks.Title: Review the work of the interview candidate
Tasks.Description:
This task is not for you as the candidate of the interview
It is here for you to check if the authorization works cause it is assigned to the interviewer.
When you fix the authorization task you should not see this anymore as a candidate.

Tasks.Title: Start the Solution from your Visual Studio
Tasks.Description:
Well done! If you see this task in your browser you already finished the first task.
Now you can start with the tasks below mark it later as finished when you built the functionality for it.
Make sure you follow the development guidelines from the Readme.md in the root of this solution.
Good luck!

Tasks.Title: Refactor TaskLogic
Tasks.Description:
IC.DotNet.Interview.Logic.BL.TaskLogic has some flaws and needs a refactor.
Keep the functionality of all the methods but make sure its clean code.

Tasks.Title: Edit functionality for tasks
Tasks.Description:
The 'Edit' button below should lead to the edit functionality of a task.
Build everything needed so the user can edit an existing task.

Tasks.Title: Store DateCreated, LastUpdated, UserCreatedId, UserLastUpdatedId for all datatypes
Tasks.Description:
Make sure the database stores for all data types the date and time when an entry was created and last updated
Also store the user which created and last updated an element in the database.

Tasks.Title: Build authentication functionality
Tasks.Description:
The Login functionality already exists
In the login form a user can enter username and password (use username: candidate and password: candidate for your tests), when the credentials were correct, the backend stores the user id of the current user in a cookie in the browser.
When the user clicks logout, the cookie is deleted.
Now build the functionality which ensures the following:
-tasks can only be seen if logged in
-a user can only see/edit/delete the tasks that are assigned to it
-a user with the role administrator can see every task
-only logged in users can create tasks
-if a creator of a task doesn't assign it, it will be assigned to the creator

Tasks.Title: Build commentary function
Tasks.Description:
Build a function which allows to comment in tasks.
The UI should display all comments (with the create date and the user who created it).

Tasks.Title: Answer questions about the architecture of the solution
Tasks.Description:
Answer the questions below in the comments of the task (if you didn't build the comments module just add your answers in a text file to the git repository):
Would you use the architecture of the solution (or parts of it) in a real project?
Why would you use which parts of the solution? Why not?
What would you change? How would you change it?

Comments.Text:
Would you use the architecture of the solution (or parts of it) in a real project?

Yes I would as this architecture is based on the Onion architecture itself and it is very good for creating compact projects which have a clear hierarchical difference amongst it's components.

Why would you use which parts of the solution? Why not?

I would probably use most of the things implemented in the "Logic " and "Web" projects(layers) such as the DI/IoC, the sparce/segragated interface principle, the structure of the project itself. Although i would consider adding in another layer and separating the Core into two separate Layers (Domain and Repository).
I wouldn't use the authentication functionallity as it is and ICollection imlementation of the datasets. The authentication isn't safe this way and the datasets are restricting us from trully replacing the object we update, instead forcing us to remove and re-add.

What would you change? How would you change it?

I would definitelly change the authentication functionallity to store and use hashed passwords and to issue authentication tokens intead of expireable cookies with an ID.
Also I would alter the ICollection of the datasets to IQueryable or IEnumerable to enable the update method to replace the old model instead of removing and re-adding it .
In a real implementation i would change some of the things I did in this excercise as well. For instance all of the authorization checks for the controller actions would be handled by a filter function as well as the required parameters. I would implement global error/validation handling rather that just showing generic messages and redirecting the user to unrestricted Views.
